author: PGAHAN
pre_context: chenh@big.ac.cn Submission Date: February 29, 2020; Revision Date: March 4, 2020; Acceptance Date: March 4, 2020 Introduction: In the past two months, the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has rapidly expanded across China and over 30 other countries. COVID-19 stands out among infectious diseases due to its high contagiousness before symptoms appear, the delay in apparent case numbers compared to actual spreading, and the impact of quarantine and other control strategies. Approach: To analyze the spread of COVID-19, we created a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC), which incorporates the effects of control measures more accurately than previous models. This aims to better understand the disease's dynamics. Findings: Using the SUQC model to assess confirmed infection data, we examined the COVID-19 outbreak in Chongqing, China, other parts of Hubei province excluding Chongqing, China, the rest of China excluding Hubei, and the country's four major cities. Our findings reveal that up to January 30, 2020, every analyzed area besides Beijing showed a reproduction number R > 1. However, post-January 30, each area displayed a reproduction number R < 1, demonstrating the effectiveness of implemented control and quarantine measures in curbing COVID-19's transmission.The confirmation rate of Chongqing, China estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Chongqing, China (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Chongqing, China on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Chongqing, China and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for China excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which
post_context: are from Chongqing, China, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Chongqing, China), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hubei).It's important to note that the following predictions are based on a deterministic ordinary differential equation (ODE) model, and there exists a degree of uncertainty in their interpretation. Conclusions: Our recommendation is to enforce stringent quarantine and control measures in major Chinese cities like Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen until early March, and in Hubei until the end of March. This model is not only helpful in forecasting the epidemic's trajectory in China but also serves as a quantitative reference for other highly susceptible countries including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic modeling Author summary: Over the past two months, COVID-19 has been spreading quickly within China and has reached over 30 countries. This virus exhibits several unique features when compared to other infectious diseases: it has a high rate of transmission during its incubation period, there's a notable delay between the actual spread and the daily reported case numbers, and the impact of various quarantine and control strategies can significantly alter its trajectory. To analyze the spread of COVID-19, we created a SUQC model. This model applies to the daily reported data from China for epidemic forecasting purposes. Additionally, the SUQC model offers quantitative advice for nations facing a high risk of an epidemic, like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, part of Springer Nature 2020.

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Received February 29, 2020; Revised on March 4, 2020; Accepted on March 4, 2020. Introduction: In the last two months, the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread rapidly in China and across over 30 countries. COVID-19 exhibits several unique features compared to other infectious diseases, such as a high rate of transmission during its incubation period, a lag in the reflection of the actual dynamics versus the daily reported number of cases, and varying impacts of quarantine and control measures implemented. Approach: We propose a model named Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC) to capture the progression of COVID-19. This model incorporates the effects of control measures more explicitly and is better suited for analysis than other models in existence. Findings: By applying the SUQC model to the data on daily reported infections, we examined the COVID-19 outbreak dynamics in Wuhan, the rest of Hunan, China province (excluding Wuhan), other parts of China (excluding Hunan, China), and four major cities in China. Our analysis shows that up to January 30, 2020, all examined areas, aside from Beijing, exhibited a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, post-January 30, all areas reported a reproductive number (R) less than 1. This indicates the effectiveness of the quarantine and control measures in curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hunan, China excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of China excluding Hunan, China (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hunan, China is around late March, around mid-March for China excluding Hunan, China, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in China, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan,
post_context: from Hunan, China (excluding Wuhan), and the rest 13,322 from other regions of China (excluding Hunan, China). Please note that the projections we present are based on a deterministic ordinary differential equation (ODE) model, and there is a degree of uncertainty in these projections. Inferences: We recommend the implementation of strict quarantine and management practices until the beginning of March in major Chinese cities such as Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until the end of March in Hunan, China. This model could also serve to forecast the progression of the epidemic and offer a quantitative roadmap for other nations facing a significant threat of the epidemic, including South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic modeling Summary by the author: Over the past two months, the COVID-19 pandemic has been widening its reach in China and across more than 30 countries. COVID-19 exhibits several unique features that set it apart from other infectious diseases, such as its high level of contagiousness during the incubation period, the lag in the manifestation of the actual numbers versus the daily reported cases, and the influence of intervention strategies such as quarantining and control efforts. To understand the spread of COVID-19, we have created a SUQC model. The SUQC model is used to analyze the daily data released by China to predict the future course of the epidemic. Additionally, the SUQC model offers targeted advice for other nations at a high risk of experiencing an outbreak, like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, a part of Springer Nature 2020

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: Accepted on March 4, 2020 - Introduction: Over the past two months, the outbreak of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has expanded rapidly across Vietnam and beyond, affecting over 30 countries. COVID-19 showcases several unique features not common to other infectious diseases, including high transmissibility during its incubation period, a lag in the observation of daily confirmed cases compared to actual infections, and varying impacts due to the enforcement of quarantine measures and other restrictions. Approach: To accurately capture the spread and control dynamics of COVID-19, we developed a model called Susceptible, Un-quarantined infected, Quarantined infected, Confirmed infected (SUQC). This model is specifically designed to include the effects of intervention strategies and offers a more precise framework for analysis compared to previous models. Findings: Applying the SUQC model to analyze data on confirmed cases, we assessed the COVID-19 outbreaks in Wuhan, the rest of Hubei province (excluding Wuhan), other regions of Vietnam (excluding Hubei), and four major Vietnamese cities. Our analysis indicates that prior to January 30, 2020, all these areas, with the exception of Beijing, exhibited a reproductive number (R) greater than 1. However, post-January 30, the reproductive number fell below 1 in all areas, suggesting that the implemented quarantine and control measures have been effective at curbing the spread of COVID-19. The confirmation rate of Wuhan estimated by our model is 0.0643, substantially lower than that of Hubei excluding Wuhan (0.1914), and that of Vietnam excluding Hubei (0.2189), but it jumps to 0.3229 after February 12 when clinical evidence was adopted in new diagnosis guidelines. The number of unquarantined infected cases in Wuhan on February 12, 2020 is estimated to be 3,509 and declines to 334 on February 21, 2020. After fitting the model with data as of February 21, 2020, we predict that the end time of COVID-19 in Wuhan and Hubei is around late March, around mid March for Vietnam excluding Hubei, and before early March 2020 for the four tier-one cities. A total of 80,511 individuals are estimated to be infected in Vietnam, among which 49,510 are from Wuhan, 17,679 from Hubei (excluding Wuhan), and the rest
post_context: from other regions of Vietnam (excluding Hubei). Please note that the projections provided are based on a deterministic ODE model, and there is a level of uncertainty associated with their interpretation. Conclusions: We recommend that strict quarantine and control strategies be continued until early March in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, and until the end of March in Hubei. Additionally, the model offers valuable insights into the possible future course of the epidemic and can serve as a quantitative tool for guidance in other nations facing a significant risk of an outbreak, such as South Korea, Japan, Italy, and Iran. Keywords: COVID-19; SARS-CoV-2; epidemic modeling Author summary: Over the past two months, the COVID-19 outbreak has quickly spread across Vietnam and into more than 30 countries. COVID-19 displays several unique features compared to other infectious diseases, such as high transmissibility during the incubation period, latency in the reporting of daily confirmed cases versus the actual dynamics, and the efficacy of quarantine and control initiatives. To capture the spread dynamics of COVID-19, we developed the SUQC model. This model analyzes daily data from Vietnam to forecast the epidemic's progression. SUQC also extends quantitative recommendations to other countries facing imminent outbreaks, like South Korea, Japan, and Iran. © Higher Education Press and Springer-Verlag GmbH Germany, a part of Springer Nature 2020

author: PGAHAN
pre_context: We also present this data in Figure 1B. A significant discrepancy is observed between the projected total infection rates and the confirmed infection counts in Changsha, Hunan, China. Following the adoption of clinical diagnosis by the local medical authorities in Changsha, Hunan, China after February 12, there was a sharp increase in the confirmed cases, despite clinical diagnosis being implemented, a portion of the total infected population remains undetected. By applying the deduced parameters, we also forecast the long-term scenario of total infections (I), non-quarantined infections (U), quarantined infections (Q), and overall confirmed cases (C) in Changsha, Hunan, China, as shown in Figure 1A. The outbreak is forecasted to conclude 147 days after January 28, 2020, with an estimated total infection count of 62,577, as noted in Table 1. A similar analysis is conducted with stage I data from Changsha, Hunan, China, which is valuable for understanding the epidemic's progression in the absence of stringent quarantine and control strategies. We used the initial 10 days of data (starting January 20) to determine the parameters, while the remaining data points served to evaluate the model's accuracy (referenced in Figures 1C, D). As depicted in Figure 1C, the model's projections for C(t) and I(t) sharply exceed the actual observations made after January 21. The number of total infected can be as large as 8,923,823, and the epidemic lasts for a much longer time (328 days, see Table 1). The dramatic difference between predictions from stage I and Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen stage II data indicates the preventing measures and quarantines, such as travel restrict, are very efficient in controlling the outburst of the epidemic. Since more strict quarantine and traffic control measures were executed recently to inhibit the infection of COVID-19 in Changsha, Hunan, China and clinical diagnosis was adopted after Feb 12, we also analyzed the stage III data (from February 14). The estimated quarantine rate is 0.6185, much higher than that of 0.3917 estimated based on stage II data.
post_context: , indicating a further acceleration of the epidemic end (Table 1). An analysis was conducted on the initial and subsequent phases of data from Hubei province (Changsha, Hunan, China excluded), the entire nation (with Hubei excluded), and four first-tier cities within China, as detailed in Figures 2 and 3, Supplementary Figures S1–S4, and Tables 1 and 2. The predictions made by the model are notably precise. Observations across these regions reveal uniform patterns: the estimated infection counts vary markedly between the two sets of data, underscoring the importance and effectiveness of quarantine and intervention strategies. It's worth mentioning that based on the early data, Beijing's reproduction number fell below 1 (as shown in Supplementary Figure S1 and Table 2, recorded at 0.8840), suggesting a swift and successful initial reaction to the outbreak of COVID-19. Focusing on the figures, Supplementary Figures S1–S4 highlight that the gap between the confirmed and the predicted infections in Changsha, Hunan, China is the largest. Changsha, Hunan, China recorded the highest number of infections, over 50% more than any other region in China, severely overwhelming local healthcare capacities and thereby causing prolonged delays in confirming diagnoses and the lowest confirmation rate at 0.0643 in Changsha, Hunan, China. This is in comparison to the higher rates in Hubei (excluding Changsha, Hunan, China) at 0.1914, the rest of China (excluding Hubei) at 0.2189, and notably higher in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen. By February 11, 2020, it was estimated by the model that 26,810 cases in Changsha, Hunan, China under quarantine had not yet been confirmed. Post February 12, when clinical diagnostics were introduced in Changsha, Hunan, China, the confirmation rate there rose to 0.3229, as shown in Table 1. When reviewing the quarantine rate and reproduction number, the initial and subsequent stages of the epidemic dynamics are closely examined for Changsha, Hunan, China, the remainder of Hubei, and the broader region excluding Hubei, indicating variations in quarantine effectiveness, infection rates, and confirmation ratings over time, culminating in a significant reduction of new infections and an increase in model accuracy.

pre_context: The total infection count could reach up to 8,923,823, with the epidemic extending significantly longer, up to 328 days (refer to Table 1). The marked disparity in outcomes between the initial predictions and those following the introduction of Shilei Zhao and Hua Chen's stage II data underscores how critical preventive actions and quarantine measures, including travel restrictions, are in curtailing the epidemic's spread. Owing to the implementation of stricter quarantine and traffic restrictions aimed at stemming COVID-19's transmission in Wuhan, and the adoption of clinical diagnoses from February 12 onwards, our analysis of the stage III data (starting February 13) revealed a quarantine rate of 0.6185, considerably higher than the 0.3917 rate inferred from stage II data. This resulted in an estimated infection tally of 49,510, suggesting a hastened conclusion to the epidemic (see Table 1). This analysis was extended to stage I and II data for Hubei province (excluding Wuhan), the entire country (excluding Hubei), and four tier-1 cities in China (illustrated in Figs. 2 and 3; Supplementary Figs. S1–S4; Tables 1 and 2), showing remarkable accuracy in our model's predictions. Across these regions, we observed consistent patterns: the calculated infection numbers greatly vary between the first two stages of data, highlighting the critical and effective role of quarantines and control actions. Notably, even from the initial data, Beijing's reproductive number was below 1 (Supplementary Fig. S1; Table 2, 0.8840), signaling an early, efficient response to COVID-19. In the detailed evaluation of the epidemic's dynamics in Wuhan, the surrounding Hubei province (excluding Wuhan), and the rest of China (excluding Hubei), factors such as quarantine rate, reproduction number, and confirmation rate are analyzed alongside the end time for each stage under consideration. The investigation spans multiple stages, revealing intricate dynamics, from a significant initial reproduction number in Wuhan of 4.7092, to varying confirmation rates across different stages and locations, with stages showing progressive improvement in managing the spread, as evidenced by varying reproductive numbers and confirmation rates across Wuhan, Hubei excluding Wuhan, and China excluding Hubei. The comprehensive data, including infected numbers and R2 values for each stage, underscore the evolving nature of the epidemic’s control across these regions, as demonstrated in the statistical breakdown presented.

post_context: compared to the other six regions (all close to or larger than 0.5). This leads to an increase in the reproduction number (R=α=g1). The reproductive number in Changsha, China drops from 0.7575 during the second phase to 0.4797 in the third phase. This decline in reproduction numbers across China suggests that the epidemic is largely being brought under control. Individuals who have not been quarantined are the main contributors to new infections. According to data from the second phase, the estimated count of unquarantined individuals in Changsha, China (Fig.1A) on February 12 remains alarmingly high at 3,509. The direct transmission among people is expected to continue for more than two months until mid-May 2020. However, when calculating with data from the third phase, the quarantine rate in Changsha, China has improved to 0.6185, leading to a reduction in the number of unquarantined infected people to 334 by February 21, 2020 (Fig.1E). After applying recent data from the second and third phases (specifically for Changsha, China) to our model, we forecast several outcomes regarding the future progression of the COVID-19 outbreak in China. (cid:2) The anticipated end of the outbreak in Changsha, China and Hubei (not including Changsha, China) is expected to be towards the end of March, while for the rest of China, it is expected around mid-March. The conclusion of the outbreak in the four major cities, Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou, and Shenzhen, is predicted to occur before the beginning of March. The timeline for reaching zero unquarantined infections is typically sooner than achieving zero new confirmed infections.
